"State code. FIPS state code as defined by FIPS PUB 5-2: Codes for the Identification of the States, the District Of Columbia and the Outlying Areas of the United States, and Associated Areas (http://www.itl.nist.gov/fipspubs/fip5-2.htm)."

"Record number is the eight-digit number that identifies the water-quality sample. The first three digits are the last three digits of the water year (1999 would be 999), and the last five digits are a data-entry sequence number."
Agency code for the sample.
Medium code identifies the material type and quality-assurance type of the sample.
Definition of the medium code.
Start date and time of sample.
Sample start date time zone.
End date and time of sample.
Sample end date time zone.
Sample local start date display. Incorporates the sample's date-precision and local time datum.
Sample UTC start date display. Incorporates the sample's date-precision.
Sample local end date display. Incorporates the sample's date-precision and local time datum.
Sample UTC start date display. Incorporates the sample's date-precision.
Time zone.
Time datum reliability code. The time datum reliability code is used to describe how well the time datum is known. Possible values: 'K' equals Known time daum.

"Hydrologic condition code identifies the relative water-level height and its direction of change during the collection of the sample. Possible values: '4' equals stable, low stage; '5' equals falling stage; '6' equals stable, high stage; '7' equals peak stage; '8' equals rising stage; '9' equals stable, normal stage; 'A' equals non determined; 'X' equals not applicable."
Sample type code identifies the QA type of a sample. Possible values: '1' equals spike; '2' equals blank; '7' equals replicate; '9' equals regular; 'H' equals composite (time).

Hydrologic event code identifies a weather event or other environmental event associated with a sample. Possible values: '1' equals drought; '3' equals regulated flow; '7' equals flood; '9' equals routine sample; 'J' equals storm; 'K' equals backwater; 'X' equals not applicable.

Taxonomic unit identification (a.k.a. tissue id). An integer number identifying a taxonomic unit in the IT IS database. See http://www.itis.usda.gov/plantproj/it is/phys_mod_all.pdf for more information.
Body part description.
Laboratory method code. The code used to identify the method used to determine a parameter value. These codes apply to more laboratories than the Central Laboratory.
Method name. A short name that partially describes a method.
Value of result parameter.
Significant figures of value of result parameter.
Rounding code of result parameter.
The result remark code qualifies the result value. Possible values: '<' equals less than; '>' equals greater than; 'A' equals average; 'E' equals estimated.
Laboratory reporting limit in effect for the parameter and method at the time the measurement was made.
Laboratory reporting limit significant figures.

Report level code is a string of alpha characters that identify the analytical reporting level appropriate for the analytical method. Possible values: '-9999' equals no value specified; 'IRL' equals interim reporting level; 'LRL' equals laboratory reporting level; 'LT-MDL' equals long term method detection level; 'MDL' equals method detection limit; 'MRL' equals minimum reporting level.
Report level name. A brief description of a report level code.
Parameter code.
Parameter-sequencing group code name.
Parameter sequencing group description.
Parameter short name.
Date and time data were loaded into the RSQA database.
Parameter code.
The Chemical Abstracts Service (CAS) Registry Number identifier for the associated chemical constituent.
Parameter group name.
Parameter group description.
Parameter short name.
Parameter reporting units defined to cooperate with descriptions by USEPA.
Parameter description.
Parameter medium.
Parameter fraction.
Indicates the temperature at which the associated parameter result value is based on or analyzed at.
"Indicates the type of statistic represented by the parameter result value. Possible values: Maximum, Mean, Median, or Minimum."
Parameter time basis.
Parameter weight basis.
Parameter particle-size basis.
Laboratory method code. The code used to identify the method used to determine a parameter value. Value definitions available at: http://help.waterdata.usgs.gov/method_cd

"Method type. A method's type. Possible values include: 'QW' equals water quality; 'SWGH' equals surface water gage height; 'SWQC' equals surface water discharge, computed; 'SWQM' equals surface water discharge, measured; 'SWVL' equals surface water velocity."
Method name. A short name that partially describes a method.
Method description. A long name that fully describes a method.
